JHU Ge;s $42,000 Wilson Grant
For Qualified Graduate Students
The Johns Hopkins University
has received a $42,000 grant from
the Woodrow Wilson National
Fellowship Foundation to subvene fellowship holders in the
University's graduate school, Sir
Hugh Taylor, President of the
Foundation, announced today.
Hopkins was one of 65 graduate schools in the United States
and Canada to benefit from tho
grant program, which disbursed
a total of $1.8 million to the 65
schools.
"Three-fourths of each grant
are earmarked for further fellowship support to students beyond their first year of graduate
study," Sir Hugh said.
Shortage Acute
"With growing college enrollments, the faculty shortage becomes more acute. Our program
increases the number of prospective teachers entering graduate
training and assists those wishing to complete their doctorates
with dispatch," he explained.
The grants to graduate schools
are in addition to the stipends

and fees paid annually to 1000
Woodrow Wilson Fellows entering their first year of graduate
training as potential college
teachers in the arts and sciences.

areas, as well as former Wood-

All We Know And Need Know
The recently instituted History of Ideas Program
at McCoy College and the proposed integrated program
in Humanities for the Graduate School have shown that
serious thought has been applied to fill in a gap that
has existed during the past few years in the humanities
program.
Unfortunately, however, the undergraduate school
conspicuously lacks any type of integrated program in
cultural history. That there is no Chicago-type Great
Books Program, and no Brandeis or Stanford-types of
History of Ideas Program is surprising in a school which
pioneered such integrated studies and which has so much
professional talent available to offer its undergraduates.
Those who disagree with us point out the Interdepartmental courses which are offered each year.
While, in principle, these inter-departmental courses
should fill in this gap in the humanities, they are really
token moves in a good direction.
What we need in this field are general introductory
or terminal courses in social science, humanities, natural science, etc. General introductory courses have
proven quite successful at a range of American universities and bear such titles as "Contemporary Civilization,"
"Medieval Civilization" or just "Humanities I,"
"Social Science III," etc. Subject matter is usually general, but integrated, and provides a realistic view of
the interrelationships of various fields.
Terminal courses of undergraduate study might
prove even more profitable than introductory studies in
an integrated program. Seminars, perhaps be organized
by centuries as in the proposed Graduate seminars.
Undergraduates could give papers anti discussed them
with their fellow students and with a professor. This
t,pe of program is conspicuous by its absence in a
school which has stressed the seminar way of education
in graduate studies.
If administrative and faculty members plea lack
of time, we need only point out the overwhelming percentage of the faculty who have taught no undergraduate course this semester. Further, ther are a good number of professors who teach introductory courses only
and are not available to undergraduates for advanced
courses in areas of their special talents.
If teaching is a primary function of a university,
and history has proved that it most assuredly is, perhaps
it is time that this university awakened to the realization that undergraduates, if only properly motivated,
could contribute much in areas of general scholarship.

At Long Last
It has long been accepted that the various organizational receptacles of undergraduate political zeal will
spend their time in grandiose plans, fiercely inconsequential rivalries anti generally noisesome dispute, arriving in the end at a pretentious impasse. So has it
always been and so, it seemed, would it always be.
But a gradual modification has taken place in the
little world of the-campus leader. The working groups,
the I.F.C., the Cotillion Board, the S.A.C., the Booster
Club go quietly about their business without too much
fuss and, it seems, with some success—the planned
"Big Weekend" leaps immediately to mind. However the
"representative" groups, the Student Council and the
D.S.R.C., have ceased their usually frenetic activity and
settled into relative obscurity. The urge to "do something" has either disappeared or been satisfied in solving
the complexities of inter committee relationships.
The point this brings to light is that the Hopkins
man is perfectly content, in general, to pursue his
studies, his amusements anti whatever else interests him
in groups of his own choosing. There seems to he no
desire for a greater extracurricular organization. In
pointing this out we do not intend to suggest that the
fashion of dissolving student governments he followed.
There is a useful and necessary function to be performed
by such a body, even in a specialized community such
as a university.
We are fortunate that a natural equilibrium has
been achieved. When necessary the Undergraduate Body
is represented by a mouthpiece which amuses itself on
ordinary occasions in absolutely harmless procedural
deliberations which satisfy the deliberators and trouble
no one else. Kudos to the 'fellows" for their outstandingly practical solution to the problem of the nature and
son-function of student government.

Salesman's Superb Acting
Provides Notable Evening
By CHARLES HOLLANDER
The Barnstormers' Dec. 14-15
production of Arthur Miller's
play, The Death Of a Salesman,
provided a wonderful evening of
theater. Expecting an inadequate
presentation of a complex theatrical expression, this reviewer
was taken aback by the first rate
tieatment the play received.
From the opening curtain, the
audience was visibly impressed
by the professional appearance
of the set, the tasteful use of
music, and the sophisticated
lighting technique. The set allowed the principals to partici-

pate in the past reveried of Willy
Loman, these comprising half
the action of the play, and innocuously slip back into time
present. The lighting was used to
indicate time shift; and, on some
occasions, it was breathtaking.
For example, upon Willy's dismissal, an ordinary brown chair
Ls spotlighted from above causing
it to appear golden and shimmering, while Willy addresses it
as though he were reconstructing a previous conversation with
his now deceased boss. He accidentally sets a dictaphone in
operation, and the audio blares

out—jolting both Willy and the
audience back to the present
This very difficult effect was
achieved with expert facility;
kudos to the backstage people.
As to the on-stage people:
Peter Grossman executed, with
frightening insight, the task of
representing a man in the
process of losing his mind; Bob
Sessions was a well-brooding
misguided Biff; Heiko Pensel
played Hap with the bravado of
a born con-man, and Linda was
aptly portrayed by Nancy Lee
Monroe as she convincingly oscillated between obedient wife
and domineering mother. The
rest of the cast was equally effective; and occasionally a minor
character stole a scene, as did

Dr. Walton Sets Record Straight,
Daniel Boone Was Not A Clod
By KEN LASSON
Trail-blazer Daniel Boone, by
far the most famous pioneer of
the Old Frontier, is suddenly the
subject of a considerable debate
concerning his merits as hero
and man. And a Hopkins professor who has more than a passing
interest in the matter wants to
set the record straight.
Dr. John Walton, head of the
Department of Education and an
expert on Boone, says that the
Kentucky hero was a genius of

lifetime." He said further that

A GUIDE FOR THE UNMONEYED
R. L. Sigafoos was a keen, ambitious lad, and when he finished
high school he wished mightily to go on with his education. It
seemed, however, a forlorn hope. R. L.'s father could not send
the boy to college because a series of crop failures had brought
him to the brink of disaster.(R. L.'s father raised orchids which,
in North Dakota, is a form of agriculture fraught with risk.)
It was, therefore, squarely up to R. L. He could go to college
only if he worked his way through. This was a prospect that
dkinayed him. He had a deep-seated fear that the task would
be too great, that he would never be able to carry on a full, busy
college life and still find time to do odd jobs and make money.
Racked with misgivings, R. L. paced the streets, pondering
his dilemma. One day, walking and brooding, he came upon a
park bench and sat down and lit a Marlboro cigarette. R. L.
always lit a Marlboro when he was low in his mind. R. L. also
always lit a Marlboro when he was merry. The fact is there is
no occasion—happy or sad, pensive or exuberant, cheery or
solemn—when Marlboro with its fine filter and fine flavor is
not entirely welcome, as you will discover when you go to your
favorite tobacconist and buy some, as we—the makers of
Marlboro and I and R. L. Sigafoos—hope you will do real soon.
Sitting and thinking and smoking a Marlboro on the park
bench, R. L. was suddenly interrupted by a small, quavering
voice which said,"My boy, you are troubled. Can I help?",

Seated beside R. L. was a tiny, gnarled man with wispy,
snow-white hair. His skin was almost transparent, showing a
delicate tracery of fragile bones beneath. His back was bent,
and his hands trembled. But his eyes were bright and clear.
R. L. looked into those eyes, into the wrinkled face. He saw
wisdom there, and experience, and kindness. "Do you think,
sir," said R. L., "that a boy can work his way through college
and still enjoy a rich, full campus life?"
"Why, bless you, son," replied the stranger with a rheumy
chuckle, "of course you can. In fact, I did it myself."
"Was it very hard?" asked R. L.
"Yes, it was hard," the stranger admitted. "But when one
Is young, all things are possible. I, for example, used to get up
at five o'clock every morning to stoke the furnace at the SAE
house. At six I had to milk the ewes at the school of animal
husbandry. At seven I gave a fencing lesson to the Dean of
Women. At eight I had a class in early Runic poets. At nine I
gave haircuts at the Gamma Phi Beta house. At ten I had differential calculus. At eleven I posed for a life class. At twelve
I watered soup at the Union. At one I had a class in Oriental
languages. At two I exercised the mice in psych lab. At three
I gave the Dean of Women another fencing lesson. At four I
had qualitative analysis. At five I went clamming. At six I cut
meat for the football team. At seven I usbed at the movies. At
eight I had my ears pierced so that at nine I could tell fortunes
in a gypsy tearoom. At ten I had a class in astronomy. At
eleven I tucked in the football team. At twelve I studied and
at three I went to sleep."
"Sir," cried It. L., "I am moved and inspired by your shining example!"
"It was nothing," said the stranger modestly, shaking his
frail white head. "It was just hard work, and hard work never
hurt anybody."
"Would you mind telling me, sir," said R. L., "how old you
are now?"
'Twenty-two," said the stranger.

north. There's good fishing, good symphonies, good art; it's a
do-or-die sports town; a land of pleasant living.
Our Company is big — but we stay close to our customers, and
closer to our personnel. Everyone gets an ample opportunity to
move up.
Yes, the future here looks good. Talk with us about it.

All We Know And Need Know
The recently instituted History of Ideas Program
at McCoy College and the proposed integrated program
in Humanities for the Graduate School have shown that
serious thought has been applied to fill in a gap that
has existed during the past few years in the humanities
program.
Unfortunately, however, the undergraduate school
conspicuously lacks any type of integrated program in
cultural history. That there is no Chicago-type Great
Books Program, and no Brandeis or Stanford-types of
History of Ideas Program is surprising in a school which
pioneered such integrated studies and which has so much
professional talent available to offer its undergraduates.
Those who disagree with us point out the Interdepartmental courses which are offered each year.
While, in principle, these inter-departmental courses
should fill in this gap in the humanities, they are really
token moves in a good direction.
What we need in this field are general introductory
or terminal courses in social science, humanities, natural science, etc. General introductory courses have
proven quite successful at a range of American universities and bear such titles as "Contemporary Civilization,"
"Medieval Civilization" or just "Humanities I,"
"Social Science III," etc. Subject matter is usually general, but integrated, and provides a realistic view of
the interrelationships of various fields.
Terminal courses of undergraduate study might
prove even more profitable than introductory studies in
an integrated program. Seminars, perhaps be organized
by centuries as in the proposed Graduate seminars.
Undergraduates could give papers anti discussed them
with their fellow students and with a professor. This
t,pe of program is conspicuous by its absence in a
school which has stressed the seminar way of education
in graduate studies.
If administrative and faculty members plea lack
of time, we need only point out the overwhelming percentage of the faculty who have taught no undergraduate course this semester. Further, ther are a good number of professors who teach introductory courses only
and are not available to undergraduates for advanced
courses in areas of their special talents.
If teaching is a primary function of a university,
and history has proved that it most assuredly is, perhaps
it is time that this university awakened to the realization that undergraduates, if only properly motivated,
could contribute much in areas of general scholarship.

At Long Last
It has long been accepted that the various organizational receptacles of undergraduate political zeal will
spend their time in grandiose plans, fiercely inconsequential rivalries anti generally noisesome dispute, arriving in the end at a pretentious impasse. So has it
always been and so, it seemed, would it always be.
But a gradual modification has taken place in the
little world of the-campus leader. The working groups,
the I.F.C., the Cotillion Board, the S.A.C., the Booster
Club go quietly about their business without too much
fuss and, it seems, with some success—the planned
"Big Weekend" leaps immediately to mind. However the
"representative" groups, the Student Council and the
D.S.R.C., have ceased their usually frenetic activity and
settled into relative obscurity. The urge to "do something" has either disappeared or been satisfied in solving
the complexities of inter committee relationships.
The point this brings to light is that the Hopkins
man is perfectly content, in general, to pursue his
studies, his amusements anti whatever else interests him
in groups of his own choosing. There seems to he no
desire for a greater extracurricular organization. In
pointing this out we do not intend to suggest that the
fashion of dissolving student governments he followed.
There is a useful and necessary function to be performed
by such a body, even in a specialized community such
as a university.
We are fortunate that a natural equilibrium has
been achieved. When necessary the Undergraduate Body
is represented by a mouthpiece which amuses itself on
ordinary occasions in absolutely harmless procedural
deliberations which satisfy the deliberators and trouble
no one else. Kudos to the 'fellows" for their outstandingly practical solution to the problem of the nature and
son-function of student government.

Salesman's Superb Acting
Provides Notable Evening
By CHARLES HOLLANDER
The Barnstormers' Dec. 14-15
production of Arthur Miller's
play, The Death Of a Salesman,
provided a wonderful evening of
theater. Expecting an inadequate
presentation of a complex theatrical expression, this reviewer
was taken aback by the first rate
tieatment the play received.
From the opening curtain, the
audience was visibly impressed
by the professional appearance
of the set, the tasteful use of
music, and the sophisticated
lighting technique. The set allowed the principals to partici-

pate in the past reveried of Willy
Loman, these comprising half
the action of the play, and innocuously slip back into time
present. The lighting was used to
indicate time shift; and, on some
occasions, it was breathtaking.
For example, upon Willy's dismissal, an ordinary brown chair
Ls spotlighted from above causing
it to appear golden and shimmering, while Willy addresses it
as though he were reconstructing a previous conversation with
his now deceased boss. He accidentally sets a dictaphone in
operation, and the audio blares

out—jolting both Willy and the
audience back to the present
This very difficult effect was
achieved with expert facility;
kudos to the backstage people.
As to the on-stage people:
Peter Grossman executed, with
frightening insight, the task of
representing a man in the
process of losing his mind; Bob
Sessions was a well-brooding
misguided Biff; Heiko Pensel
played Hap with the bravado of
a born con-man, and Linda was
aptly portrayed by Nancy Lee
Monroe as she convincingly oscillated between obedient wife
and domineering mother. The
rest of the cast was equally effective; and occasionally a minor
character stole a scene, as did
Kostia Bergman (as cousin
Bernard, the archtypal fink) and

By KEN LASSON

A GUIDE FOR THE UNMONEYED
R. L. Sigafoos was a keen, ambitious lad, and when he finished
high school he wished mightily to go on with his education. It
seemed, however, a forlorn hope. R. L.'s father could not send
the boy to college because a series of crop failures had brought
him to the brink of disaster.(R. L.'s father raised orchids which,
in North Dakota, is a form of agriculture fraught with risk.)
It was, therefore, squarely up to R. L. He could go to college
only if he worked his way through. This was a prospect that
dkinayed him. He had a deep-seated fear that the task would
be too great, that he would never be able to carry on a full, busy
college life and still find time to do odd jobs and make money.
Racked with misgivings, R. L. paced the streets, pondering
his dilemma. One day, walking and brooding, he came upon a
park bench and sat down and lit a Marlboro cigarette. R. L.
always lit a Marlboro when he was low in his mind. R. L. also
always lit a Marlboro when he was merry. The fact is there is
no occasion—happy or sad, pensive or exuberant, cheery or
solemn—when Marlboro with its fine filter and fine flavor is
not entirely welcome, as you will discover when you go to your
favorite tobacconist and buy some, as we—the makers of
Marlboro and I and R. L. Sigafoos—hope you will do real soon.
Sitting and thinking and smoking a Marlboro on the park
bench, R. L. was suddenly interrupted by a small, quavering
voice which said,"My boy, you are troubled. Can I help?",

Seated beside R. L. was a tiny, gnarled man with wispy,
snow-white hair. His skin was almost transparent, showing a
delicate tracery of fragile bones beneath. His back was bent,
and his hands trembled. But his eyes were bright and clear.
R. L. looked into those eyes, into the wrinkled face. He saw
wisdom there, and experience, and kindness. "Do you think,
sir," said R. L., "that a boy can work his way through college
and still enjoy a rich, full campus life?"
"Why, bless you, son," replied the stranger with a rheumy
chuckle, "of course you can. In fact, I did it myself."
"Was it very hard?" asked R. L.
"Yes, it was hard," the stranger admitted. "But when one
Is young, all things are possible. I, for example, used to get up
at five o'clock every morning to stoke the furnace at the SAE
house. At six I had to milk the ewes at the school of animal
husbandry. At seven I gave a fencing lesson to the Dean of
Women. At eight I had a class in early Runic poets. At nine I
gave haircuts at the Gamma Phi Beta house. At ten I had differential calculus. At eleven I posed for a life class. At twelve
I watered soup at the Union. At one I had a class in Oriental
languages. At two I exercised the mice in psych lab. At three
I gave the Dean of Women another fencing lesson. At four I
had qualitative analysis. At five I went clamming. At six I cut
meat for the football team. At seven I usbed at the movies. At
eight I had my ears pierced so that at nine I could tell fortunes
in a gypsy tearoom. At ten I had a class in astronomy. At
eleven I tucked in the football team. At twelve I studied and
at three I went to sleep."
"Sir," cried It. L., "I am moved and inspired by your shining example!"
"It was nothing," said the stranger modestly, shaking his
frail white head. "It was just hard work, and hard work never
hurt anybody."
"Would you mind telling me, sir," said R. L., "how old you
are now?"
'Twenty-two," said the stranger.
